--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Vladimir R. Bossicard" <vladimir@b...>
wrote:
> > Could you clarify what you mean by "not need a runner" and how
that 
> > influenced the design of TestResult?
> 
> it goes something like this:
> 
> TestResult result = new TestResult();
> TestCase test = new MyTestCase("testXYZ");
> test.run(result);
> if (result.wasSuccessful()) {
>    S.o.p("hurra!");
> }
> 
> no need for a TestRunner to execute the test.
> 
I see. The original intent was that users would write their own
runner-esque 
code to run their tests.

> I don't particularly like the TestResult and would replace it by
some listener
> architecture.  But you couldn't run a test without TestRunner like
in the 
above
> example anymore.
>
Do you mean besides the TestListeners that can register themselves
with 
TestResult itself?

A listener architecture is kind of what we do in SuiteRunner, in that
you can 
specify multiple Reporters for a single test run, as many as you
want. The 
Runner app puts the specified Reporters into a DispatchReporter,
which 
forwards all method invocations to each specified Reporter. The tests 
themselves need only ever make reports to one Reporter, which in the
case of 
Runner, is the DispatchReporter. This is similar to registering
multiple 
TestListeners with TestResult, then passing a single TestResult down
into the 
tests.
 
> > > if every test share the same resources, you can potentially
have some 
> > > very tricky problems:
> 
> > Instead of creating a fixture in the constructor and reusing it
in each 
> > test method -- hoping that testA doesn't screw up the fixture in
a way 
> > that causes testZ to fail -- you just recreate the fixture anew
before 
> > each test method.
> 
> If you recreate a fixture before each test, you're not _sharing_ a
fixture.  The
> problem appears when the tests truly share a fixture and when they
rely on
> another test's result for their execution (like in a
create-update-delete test
> sequence).
> 
That's true, but I still have the question: What does running each
test method 
in its own instance buy you that setUp and tearDown don't already buy
you? 
The only advantage I can see is that you can screw up your setUp
method by 
forgetting to recreate something. Running each test method in its own 
instance shields you from any problem.

Also, is it not true that by forcing every test method into its own
instance, then 
tests can't share a fixture. So not only can you never encounter the
potential 
problems of sharing a fixture, you also aren't able to reap any
benefits of 
sharing a fixture. What do you usually tell people who want testB to
use the 
results of testA?
